_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Redding has instituted a Risk Management Program for their wastewater treatment facility, Clear Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant, as required by Federal Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) Program regulations at 40 CFR Part 68 and administered by Shasta County EHD.  The Risk Management Program identifies the equipment, procedures, maintenance, inspection, and training associated with Regulated Substances (RS's) handled at this facility in excess of Federal threshold quantities; describes the structured assessment of hazards which was conducted to assess possible onsite effects on employees and offsite public and environmental receptors; provides the results of an offsite consequences analysis.  It defines a prevention program, emergency response program, and mitigation measures to reduce the probability and magnitude of accidental releases of RS's; and establishes a schedule and responsibilities for implementing mitigation measures including auditing the program.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP)is being filed as required by ARP regulations in order to report the elements of the current Risk Management Program and to describe further measures planned to mitigate or prevent accidental releases of RS's.  

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The City of Redding operates two wastewater treatment plants: Clear Creek and Stillwater.  Clear Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant is located at 2220 Metz Road, Anderson, CA in Shasta County. It uses chlorine and sulfur dioxide for effluent disinfection and dechlorination prior to release to the Sacramento River.  Both chemicals are stored and used onsite in quantities greater than the Federal threshold quantities.  Clear Creek is located on the west bank of the Sacramento River in an industrial area just south of Redding.  There are 12 full-time employees at this site.  Chlorine and sulfur dioxide are received in ton containers by truck, handled with an electric hoist, and stored in separate rooms inside

an enclosed building that is dedicated to chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  The chlorine is used for odor control of the influent wastewater, to disinfect the wastewater effluent, and for other process uses.  The sulfur dioxide is used to dechlorinate the disinfected effluent for aquatic toxicity control.  Pressurized gas within each ton container is reduced to vacuum using a vacuum regulator valve mounted directly onto the ton container's gas valve.  The gas, under vacuum from up to four ton containers, is connected to a manifold where it is metered through rate valves and rotameters in chlorinators or sulfonators located in a separate room.  For chlorine, the gas is drawn into water solution by the passage of pressurized water through an injector inside the dedicated building.  In the case of sulfur dioxide, the gas under partial vacuum travels underground in PVC piping to the outfall building where it is injected into water and then added to the outfall pipe shortly before the final effluent is discharged into the Sacramento River.

The City removed sulfur dioxide in 2023 due to the lack of the chemical being available. This RMP employs predictive filing and the City would return to using sulfur dioxide if it becomes available again.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

It is the policy of the City of Redding that the receipt, storage and handling of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at its facility be done in a manner which meets regulatory requirements and minimizes the probability and severity of accidental releases of chlorine to the atmosphere, in order to protect the health and safety of its workers, the public, and the environment.  In order to accomplish this goal, the City of Redding has:
1	gathered safety information on chlorine and sulfur dioxide and on the process, equipment and procedures involving chlorine and sulfur dioxide; 
2	performed a structured assessment of hazards of the process and external events which might affect the p

rocess; 
3	performed an offsite consequences analysis of defined release scenarios; 
4	established a written program for prevention and mitigation of accidental releases; and 
5	established a written emergency response program coordinated with emergency response agencies.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAMS

General accidental release prevention programs instituted by the City of Redding are categorized as administrative (management) programs; procedures, training, and engineering controls; and emergency response programs. City of Redding has instituted a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program meeting OSHA requirements at 29 CFR 1910.119 covering its disinfection and dechlorination process.  This constitutes the general accidental release prevention program for the City of Redding's operations.  The program and document management procedures included in the PSM Program are used as the management system for the Risk Management Program.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC RELEASE PREVENTION STEPS

Release prevention steps specific to chlorine and sulfur dioxide have been identified and implemented.  These include, among other things, enclosing the chlorine and sulfur dioxide building, improving the seismic restraint of ton containers and container scales, and adding a dry media neutralization (scrubber) to remove accidentally release gas into the building before it can lead to an atmospheric release.  Chlorine and sulfur dioxide stored onsite has been reduced to a minimum.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no reportable accidents involving chlorine or sulfur dioxide at this facility within the past five years resulting in injuries or offsite consequences.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The City of Redding's Emergency Response Program applicable to chlorine has been coordinated with Redding Fire Department. The City of Redding maintains First Responder capability with respect to chlorine and sulfur dioxide releases at its facilities.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SA

FETY

All of the improvements and mitigation measures identified in the process hazard analysis which the City of Redding committed to accomplish have been completed or are in progress.  Any other measures identified by employees during workplace hazard surveys, or as a result of audit activities, will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.  Disposition of these recommendations can be found in the committed action tracking log.
